1.text: Dead flies cause the ointment of the apothecary to stink [and] ferment; [so] a little folly is weightier than wisdom [and] honour.

2.text: The heart of a wise [man] is at his right hand; but a fool’s heart at his left.

3.text: Yea also, when he that is a fool walketh by the way, his sense faileth [him], and he saith to every one [that] he is a fool.

4.text: If the spirit of the ruler rise up against thee, leave not thy place; for quietness pacifieth great offences.

5.text: There is an evil that I have seen under the sun, as an error [that] proceedeth from the ruler:

6.text: folly is set in great dignities, but the rich sit in a low place.

7.text: I have seen servants upon horses, and princes walking as servants upon the earth.

8.text: He that diggeth a pit falleth into it; and whoso breaketh down a hedge, a serpent biteth him.

9.text: Whoso removeth stones is hurt therewith; he that cleaveth wood is endangered thereby.

10.text: If the iron be blunt, and one do not whet the edge, then must he apply more strength; but wisdom is profitable to give success.

11.text: If the serpent bite before enchantment, then the charmer hath no advantage.

12.text: The words of a wise man’s mouth are gracious; but the lips of a fool swallow up himself.

13.text: The beginning of the words of his mouth is folly; and the end of his talk is mischievous madness.

14.text: And the fool multiplieth words: [yet] man knoweth not what shall be; and what shall be after him, who will tell him?

15.text: The labour of fools wearieth them, because they know not how to go to the city.

16.text: Woe to thee, O land, when thy king is a child, and thy princes eat in the morning!

17.text: Happy art thou, O land, when thy king is a son of nobles, and thy princes eat in [due] season, for strength, and not for drunkenness!

18.text: By much sloth fulness the framework falleth in; and through idleness of the hands the house drippeth.

19.text: A feast is made for laughter, and wine maketh life merry; but money answereth everything.

20.text: Curse not the king, no, not in thy thought; and curse not the rich in thy bedchamber: for the bird of the air will carry the voice, and that which hath wings will tell the matter.
